;

; Mon, 13 Nov 2023 14:22:01 +0800 High silver levels in some period pants could pose health risk, study sayshttps://www.theguardian.com/society/2023/nov/13/high-silver-levels-some-period-pants-could-pose-health-risk-study

;;一位年轻女子双手放在肚子上的特写
;

;出售一些古裤一项调查发现，商业街零售商生产的产品含有高含量的银，可能会对消费者的健康和环境产生影响。

;

;银被用作抗菌剂，通常添加到经期裤中，以消除用户对银的担忧。气味和卫生。

;

;然而，科学家们越来越多地警告潜在的健康影响。美国食品和药物管理局发现纳米银可以杀死乳酸菌，这是阴道中有助于抵抗感染的健康细菌。这可能会使经期裤使用者面临更多有害细菌的风险，从而可能导致细菌感染和妊娠并发症的风险增加。

;

;Which? 家居产品和服务主管娜塔莉·希钦斯 (Natalie Hitchins) 表示：“消费者应谨慎购买含银的经期裤，因为专家担心其对健康的影响。

;

;“哪个？认为品牌还应该明确说明哪些产品含有银，以便购物者可以就自己购买的商品和可能的风险做出明智的决定。”

;

;消费者权益组织与意大利消费者组织 Altroconsumo 合作，进行独立测试受欢迎的品牌，并检查它们是否含有任何令人担忧的化学物质。他们担心一些产品含有大量的银，而包装上并不总是明确说明这一点。

;

;Bodyform 的 Intima 和 Marks & 的裤子。尤其是 Spencer 的银含量明显高于其他品牌，分别为 126.7 毫克/公斤和 57.8 毫克/公斤。其他品牌的含量分别为 8.3 毫克/公斤、7.4 毫克/公斤和 0.9 毫克/公斤。

;

;Bodyform 和 Modibodi 的所有者 Essity 表示，银铜沸石用于“防止穿着裤子时产生异味”。长达 12 小时”。该公司补充说，其所有“可洗内衣均经过 Oeko-Tex Standard 100 认证，这意味着每一个成分都经过了有害物质测试”，并且“内衣已被指定为对人体健康无害”。

;

;标记和标记斯宾塞拒绝发表评论。

;

;哪一个？表示认为没有必要使用银，并且 Altroconsumo 之前的测试表明，以这种方式处理的纺织品不具有承诺的抗菌性能。

;

;欧洲化学品管理局表示银处理，例如纳米银和银沸石，对水生生物有毒并具有长期影响。

;

;测试哪些？检测结果显示，银含量超过0.1毫克/公斤，而Primark、Repeat、Wuka、Lovable和Sloggi裤子中均未发现银含量。 Sloggi 的网站称其确实使用了银基抗菌剂，而 Primark 则表示其使用了含有氯化银的 Micro-Fresh。

;

;Primark 发言人表示：“经期裤的性质意味着有可能穿着过程中会产生气味（就像细菌会导致袜子和鞋子在穿着过程中产生气味一样），而我们的抗菌表面处理可最大限度地减少此类气味。”

;

;Sloggi 没有回复“哪个？”在发布时。

;

;英国对于古裤中可以添加多少银没有法律限制。制造商不必在其包装或网站上声明银的存在。

; Mon, 13 Nov 2023 13:22:01 +0800 Woman who suffered complications from vaginal mesh implant awarded at least £1mhttps://www.theguardian.com/society/2023/nov/13/woman-suffered-complications-vaginal-mesh-implant-awarded-1m

;;Yvette Greenway-Mansfield
;

;一名因阴道网状植入物而遭受创伤性并发症的妇女已被NHS 获得了至少 100 万英镑的创纪录和解金。

;

;59 岁的 Yvette Greenway-Mansfield 于 2009 年在考文垂大学医院接受了网状植入，但随后出现了严重的并发症。她对医院信托基金提出的医疗过失索赔发现，手术过早进行且没有必要，而且她的同意书在格林威-曼斯菲尔德签署后经过修改，加入了额外的风险。

;

;格林威-曼斯菲尔德表示，获得赔偿是一种“巨大的解脱”，但她补充说，许多其他遭受类似损害的妇女只得到很少或根本没有得到赔偿，并批评政府的;未能为受害者建立经济赔偿机构;。

;

;“我不是唯一一个。有成千上万的我，”她说。 “应该有一大笔钱来为这些女性提供损害赔偿，并制定一个护理计划，作为对网状受损人群的自动反应。这归根结底是对妇女和妇女健康问题的看法。我们都已经受够了。”

;

;格林威-曼斯菲尔德 (Greenway-Mansfield) 最初于 2009 年去看了全科医生，当时她出现下腹部不适和排尿频率增加，导致对喝水感到焦虑。她的症状归因于子宫脱垂，一位妇科医生顾问建议进行阴道子宫切除术，并插入经阴道胶带 (TVT) 网状植入物。

;

;最初，手术似乎很成功，但在 2017 年，在去新西兰出差时，她开始感到疼痛和出血。 “当我回到英国后，有人认为网状物可能已经开始侵蚀阴道壁，”格林威-曼斯菲尔德说。 “听到这个信息我很震惊，因为我不知道会发生这样的并发症。”

; ;

;她疼痛变得更加严重，但她被告知没有明显的医疗解决方案。 2020 年 2 月，在私人转诊至 Spire Bristol 医院后，网片被移除，但她现在患有尿失禁和大便失禁以及慢性疼痛。

;

;声明发现 Greenway-Mansfield 的表格同意手术她签字后就被更改了。医院的版本包括膀胱镜检查和额外的风险，包括失败、胶带腐蚀、疼痛、膀胱过度活动症和深静脉血栓形成。这些内容并不在格林威-曼斯菲尔德的原件复本上，她保留了原件。 “我简直不敢相信我所看到的，”格林威-曼斯菲尔德说。 “我觉得自己完全被证明是正确的。”

;

;“如果我没有保留这些文件，我可能会站在法庭上，受到盘问，被证明是一个骗子，”她说。 “对于必须经历这些的女性来说，这让我心碎。”

;

;手术也被认为是在探索其他选择（例如物理治疗和膀胱训练）之前进行的。

; < p>;;Neil Clayton;，代表 Greenway-Mansfield 的 Lime Solicitors 临床过失合伙人表示：“考文垂和沃里克郡 NHS 信托大学医院有义务确保获得格林威-曼斯菲尔德夫人对任何外科手术的完全知情同意，并告知她由此可能出现的风险。”

;

; “妇科医生在用尽所有行为和医疗选择之前过早地进行了手术。而且，她在错误的情况下进行了错误的手术，不必要地进行了手术。尤其令人震惊的是，格林威-曼斯菲尔德夫人签署了一份同意书，该同意书后来被修改，其中包括了她从未意识到的风险。

;

;“没有多少钱可以完全补偿格林威-曼斯菲尔德夫人所遭受的痛苦。考文垂和沃里克郡 NHS 信托大学医院的发言人表示： “我们直接向 Greenway-Mansfield 女士表示最诚挚的歉意，并认识到她的生活受到 2009 年这一手术的影响。自 2019 年以来，英国已暂停提供使用阴道网片治疗压力性尿失禁或盆腔器官脱垂的手术，并于 2022 年创建了专科中心。”

;

;“我们希望和解协议将使 Greenway-Mansfield 夫人能够满足她持续的护理需求，并为她和她的家人的未来提供安全保障。”

;

; Mon, 13 Nov 2023 10:22:02 +0800 England stop and search pilot scheme does not cut violence, thinktank findshttps://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/nov/13/england-stop-and-search-does-not-cut-violence-thinktank
;;2023-11-13T00:01:17Z;
;
;;Police carrying out stop and search
;

;A pilot scheme that allows police to stop and search people without having any grounds for suspicion does not work to reduce serious violence and disproportionately targets people of colour, a report has concluded.

;

;In the first comprehensive review of evidence on stop and search and serious violence reduction orders (SVROs), the racial equality thinktank Runnymede Trust found that there was no statistically significant link between existing police stop and search powers and violence prevention or reduction.

;

;The study also showed that people from ethnic minority backgrounds, and particularly Black people, were more likely to be stopped and searched, and experience negative mental and physical health outcomes as a result.

;

;SVROs are court orders that allow officers to search people who have been convicted of an offence that involved a “bladed article or offensive weapon”, even if there are no immediate grounds for thinking they are carrying one at that time.

;

;This order, introduced as a pilot under the Police Crime Sentencing and Courts Act 2022, can last for between six months and two years, though it can be extended.

;

;It is a criminal offence for someone with an SVRO to obstruct officers conducting a search or to deny having the order if asked. The orders are being piloted in Thames Valley, West Midlands, Merseyside and Sussex.

;

;The Runnymede Trust said the court orders were “part of a broader expansion of police powers and the rolling-back of safeguards and avenues for police accountability”, citing the poor outcomes relating to stop-and-search powers used without reasonable suspicion.

;

;Section 60 search powers, under which police officers can stop and search a person without reasonable suspicion, are particularly ineffective, the thinktank said, with an overall arrest ;rate of 0.5% for offensive weapons between 2001 and 2021;.

;

;Dr Tim Head, an author of the report and a criminology lecturer at the University of Essex, said: “One of the most striking things about the government's introduction of serious violence reduction order powers is that next to no evidence has been cited to support their rollout.

;

;“However you frame it, the vast majority of rigorous evidence on SVROs points towards a single conclusion: high-discretion police stop interventions like this do not 'work', even on their own terms. Instead, they produce harm, anxiety and misery among the communities they purport to 'protect'.”

;

;SVROs were ;proposed in 2019 by Boris Johnson in an attempt to tackle knife crime;. The idea was first set out by the rightwing Centre for Social Justice thinktank and supported by the former Conservative leader and ex-work and pensions secretary, Iain Duncan Smith.

;

;A ;report by the Home Office last year showed that people from Black, Asian and other minority ethnic backgrounds were likely to be targeted; under relaxed stop and search rules, despite not having committed crimes.

;

;In the 12 months to June 2020, Black people were 3.7 times more likely to be stopped than white people. This figure rose to 6.9 times for stops relating to weapons, points and blades and section 60.

;

;The report also highlights that the stop and search orders are detrimental to the mental and physical health of those targeted, and called for the SVRO pilot to be scrapped and replaced by a community-led, evidence-based approach.

; Mon, 13 Nov 2023 08:52:01 +0800 Deal to resettle climate-hit Tuvalu residents shows world ‘what’s at stake’, European officials sayhttps://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/nov/13/australia-tuvalu-pacific-islands-climate-emissions-europe
;;2023-11-12T20:53:13Z;
;
;;Tuvalu
;

;Australia's residency offer to citizens from the low-lying Pacific country of Tuvalu must spur the world to dramatically cut emissions, two senior European officials have declared.

;

;Germany's climate envoy, Jennifer Morgan, said the deal “puts a very clear pointer on what's at stake” as the negotiators prepare for next month's UN climate summit, adding that “all countries have to scale up their ambition for 2030”.

;

;The message was echoed by a senior European Union official, Koen Doens, who said the climate crisis was putting Pacific island countries under increasing stress and more urgent action was “absolutely essential”.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Tuvalu residency and security treaty: what is it and why is Australia doing it?;

;
;

;The comments follow the Australian government's announcement that it would offer up to 280 people from Tuvalu access to residency, work and study rights each year, as part of a new treaty that also ;binds the two countries closely together on security;.

;

;The deal is driven by recognition that Tuvalu – a country of nine low-lying islands about halfway between Australia and Hawaii – is particularly vulnerable to rising sea levels.

;
    ;
  • ;

    ;;;Sign up for Guardian Australia's free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup;;

    ;
    • ;
;

;But Australia has also promised to fund coastal adaptation projects – including land reclamation work around the capital, Funafuti – to help as many as possible of Tuvalu's 11,200 citizens “stay in their homes with safety and dignity”.

;

;Speaking to the Guardian on the sidelines of a Pacific summit in Cook Islands, where the deal was announced, Morgan said the news was “attracting attention” in Germany.

;

;“What I've heard back from friends – not climate people – in Germany is that they're very sad about the fact that a country like Tuvalu has to be thinking about where their people may have to go,” Morgan said.

;

;She called for “even more focus on driving down emissions to avoid that, so that people can stay in their homes”.

;

;Morgan said the world must not abandon the goal of limiting global heating to 1.5C above pre-industrial levels, saying this was “a matter of life and death for many people here in this region”.

;

;Doens, the European Commission's director general for international partnerships, said the Australia-Tuvalu treaty was “a very impactful agreement”.

;

;“We all know what is happening to some of the islands in the Pacific. We know what is happening to Tuvalu,” he told the Guardian.

;

;“The stress on the people living on the islands is increasing.”

;
;

;;Related: ;;Australia to offer residency to Tuvalu citizens displaced by climate change;

;
;

;Doens also called for “a more ambitious climate mitigation agenda than what we are seeing from the global community”.

;

;The US ambassador to the UN, Linda Thomas-Greenfield, who also visited Cook Islands, told reporters the climate crisis was having “a disproportionate impact on Pacific island nations”.

;

;Asked whether the Australia-Tuvalu agreement was a sign of things to come, she said: “We have seen these displacements take place already, not just here in the Pacific but across the world.

;

;“We see environmental migration, if you just look at the situation in the Sahel, where you see people moving across the Mediterranean. So the Australian announcement, I think, is a positive response to that movement.”

;

;The comments came after the Pacific Islands Forum (Pif) – whose 18 members include Australia and New Zealand – wrapped up ;its most important annual political summit;.

;

;Despite many Pacific island leaders wishing to explicitly call for a phase-out of fossil fuels, the final communique include caveats that were seen to be heavily influenced by Australia.

;

;The Cook Islands prime minister and summit host, Mark Brown, confirmed that leaders “aspired” to phasing out fossil fuels while acknowledging the pathway was “not immediate nor one size fits all”.

;

;The summit also rebuffed calls by a group of former Pacific leaders to make Australia's bid to ;co-host the 2026 Cop UN climate summit; conditional on it stopping new coal and gas developments.

;

;The Pif secretary general, Henry Puna, said the regional grouping had already agreed to promote the joint bid, “keeping in mind that Australia has already committed to making this the Pacific Cop”.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Climate crisis and China-US rivalry: five top takeaways from the Pacific's most important summit;

;
;

;But he said advancing the bid had to be “done by consensus”. That was likely a reference to the “western European and other states” – a UN grouping that will be decisive in who hosts the 2026 conference. Germany is in that group.

;

;Morgan reiterated Germany's support, saying her country was “quite positive about the approach of having the Pacific islands going hand in hand with Australia on that bid”.

;

;“We would expect, of course, that the Pacific islands' priorities and goals would play a big role in how that Cop is carried out,” Morgan added. “And being here just reinforces that even more.”

;

;Shiva Gounden, the Greenpeace Pacific adviser, said the Australian government should prove its seriousness by no longer approving new fossil fuel projects – “something Pacific leaders and civil society have been crying out for in very clear terms”.

;

;The Pacific Islands Climate Action Network's regional coordinator, Lavetanalagi Seru, described the Australia-Tuvalu pact as “a mere Band-Aid solution that in no way adequately addresses the fossil-fuelled climate crisis”.

;

;The Climate Council senior researcher Wesley Morgan said Australia's “first responsibility must be to get emissions down as fast as possible” to minimise the risk of people being forced from their homes.
